So said  Curt Sampson  on  2/9/2003 --------------------

<snip />
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger <jbr@...>
>>
>> If I test your implementation rather than just checking the SQL
>> string, then I have to run that [taking a lot of time] OR I simply
>> don't run those tests. (If I knew ahead of time what would break,
then
>> I wouldn't want to run all the tests all the time, but I don't, so I
>> do.)
>
>I read this as you suggesting that you want to run all the tests and
>have reasonable coverage, but you don't want to run the SQL code. That
>makes no sense to me; if you're not running the SQL code, you're not
>testing it.

You're right. I'm not testing that the SQL code is correct because:

(1) Continually testing it is expensive, and
(2) I tested it at least once, and
(3) Re-testing it only finds bugs in either the environment or the
underlying database management system

Remember that part of the point of these tests is to enable me to make
changes and see the consequences of those things. That way I am
aggressive and make changes without fear of unknowingly breaking some
part of the system.

If I don't change the DBMS nor the operating environment, then the SQL
statements, once correct, cannot break. They become a "golden master"
against which I can continue to compare as needed.

Better would be to have some in-memory SQL syntax/semantics checker
that worked against my database schema, simulated the statements and
ensured that they continue to make sense. Failing that, I choose to
accept the risk that my SQL statements suddenly stop working, even if I
don't change them.

But like I said, if I move all the SQL statements into one place, I can
easily write a simple test to verify those statements against the
database. I can run that test less frequently, thus avoiding the
overhead of running them all the time.

>Proving that the SQL code compares to some arbitrary string
>is not at all the same thing as saying that, when executed, it does
the
>right thing in the context of the application, and the surrounding
Java
>code that uses the result of that SQL statement does the right thing.

But once I verify that the SQL statements are correct, if I don't
change them, they never stop working. (My assumptions are listed
above.)

>In other words, it sounds like you're not testing the entire
application
>at all. You're just hoping the SQL will work, rather than proving it
by
>actually executing it and verifying the results.

No, I think I either misspoke or you misread. See the above.

>(And as I said, the tests do not take nearly as long as you've
>suggested, if you set things up properly. There are lots of tricks,
such
>as using very small sets of sample data for the unit tests, that help
>keep things moving quickly.)

I agree; however, now my tests depend on the database. I don't want my
PTs to depend on such an expensive resource. My CTs or some mid-level
integration tests, perhaps; but not my PTs. That's not the role they
play.

I hope that the above make my position clearer.
